Answer: Yes, Twitter is the greatest technological innovation ever. To heck with fire, flint axes, the bow and arrow, fishing hooks and nets, agriculture, the lever, the inclined plane, the arch, metallurgy, carpentry, electricity, plumbing, radio, the transistor, liquid crystal displays, packet-switching networks, cell phones, the Internet protocols, and the web browser.
name: Ethan Hein
question: https://www.quora.com/What-type-of-engineering-should-I-learn-to-be-able-to-make-innovative-revolutionary-technologies

Answer: “Might we see a revolutionary technology that will cure or change our relationship with all diseases in our lifetimes?”A curative technology change forA relational technology change for all diseases is more likely.
name: Sean Kernan
question: https://www.quora.com/What-type-of-engineering-should-I-learn-to-be-able-to-make-innovative-revolutionary-technologies

Answer: Maybe. If we understand genetics deeply enough we might change our relationship with diseases (both in what we can treat and in how we approach treatment). Conversely, are we going to cure all diseases? No, because that would include curing vulnerability to infections, toxins, and epigenetic changes.However, we actually don’t want to cure all diseases. If we were to cure all disease then we would have to determine a way for people to die, other than truly falling apart. We are not nearly smart enough to build appropriate systems for managing our role on the planet in such a scenario. We are toMaybe. If we understand genetics deeply enough we might change our relationship with diseases (both in what we can treat and in how we approach treatment). Conversely, are we going to cure all diseases? No, because that would include curing vulnerability to infections, toxins, and epigenetic changes.However, we actually don’t want to cure all diseases. If we were to cure all disease then we would have to determine a way for people to die, other than truly falling apart. We are not nearly smart enough to build appropriate systems for managing our role on the planet in such a scenario. We are too selfish, to focused on trivial things. As a species we do not yet have the grace nor wisdom to determine how to live constructively and then get out of the way and let someone else have a turn.
name: Marc Lawrence
question: https://www.quora.com/Might-we-see-a-revolutionary-technology-that-will-cure-or-change-our-relationship-with-all-diseases-in-our-lifetimes

Answer: I think anything is possible with all the research that is always in progress. We are constantly discovering new things about how the body works, how diseases work, and how they are affected by various ‘assaults’.
